citations.narrative:
Two incidents occurred involving birds getting attacked by predators while in their enclosure:
- On February 10, 2024, a predator entered the aviary by digging a path underneath the enclosure’s boardwalk. The
predator, likely a fox per the facility’s investigation, killed 2 ducks as well as a waldrapp ibis and injured another ibis.
- On March 23, 2024, a predator attacked a white cockatoo named Pebbles in her primary enclosure. Puncture wounds
were found along the left side of the bird’s neck and the left eye. Pebbles received medical attention but was found dead
three days later, on March 26, 2024.
The enclosure did not protect the birds and did not prevent predators from accessing, injuring and killing the animals.
Housing facilities must protect the birds from injury and restrict other animals from entering that may negatively affect the
welfare of the birds within. Corrective actions were implemented at the time of inspection.

On December 20, 2023, four of the eight foxes escaped their enclosure the day after arrival at the facility. The foxes were
housed in an enclosure with indoor and outdoor access. The foxes gained access to the adjacent enclosure by digging
under the chain link shift door of the outdoor portion and escaped through a hole created by staff in that second enclosure
in order to evaluate the dig barrier there. Three of the foxes were found unarmed on the same day; two were herded back
while the third was captured with a net and placed back into the enclosure. The fourth fox was found unharmed near the
commissary 8 days later and captured with a net to be placed back into the enclosure. The enclosure did not adequately
contain the animals. Primary enclosures must be constructed of such material and of such strength to safely contain the
animals. Corrective actions were implemented at the time of inspection.

Most of the animals within the facility have outdoor or sheltered housing. The chain link perimeter fence located behind
the maintenance area and the parrot enclosures had the following deficiencies:
- Large gaps, some reaching up to about 1.5 feet in height and others spanning long distances, were seen at the bottom
of the fence in many different areas.
- Thick vegetation overgrowth climbing and leaning over large sections of the fence created a ladder that may allow
unwanted animals to easily enter the facility.
The lack of an adequate perimeter fence presents a safety risk to the animals within the facility in that there isn’t a
sufficient barrier to keep animals and unauthorized persons out, or an adequate secondary containment system to hold
animals that may escape their primary enclosures. The facility must ensure the perimeter fence is kept in good repair and
at the proper height in order to stand as an adequate barrier to protect the animals within the facility. Correct by
09/19/2024.
This inspection and exit interview were conducted with facility representatives.
n

narrative:
3.150(a)  Critical
   
Facilities, general. 
Two incidents occurred involving birds getting attacked by predators while in their enclosure: 
- On February 10, 2024, a predator entered the aviary by digging a path underneath the enclosure’s boardwalk. The 
predator, likely a fox per the facility’s investigation, killed 2 ducks as well as a waldrapp ibis and injured another ibis.  
- On March 23, 2024, a predator attacked a white cockatoo named Pebbles in her primary enclosure. Puncture wounds 
were found along the left side of the bird’s neck and the left eye. Pebbles received medical attention but was found dead 
three days later, on March 26, 2024.  
The enclosure did not protect the birds and did not prevent predators from accessing, injuring and killing the animals. 
Housing facilities must protect the birds from injury and restrict other animals from entering that may negatively affect the 
welfare of the birds within. Corrective actions were implemented at the time of inspection. 
3.125(a)  Repeat
   
Facilities, general. 
On December 20, 2023, four of the eight foxes escaped their enclosure the day after arrival at the facility. The foxes were 
housed in an enclosure with indoor and outdoor access. The foxes gained access to the adjacent enclosure by digging 
under the chain link shift door of the outdoor portion and escaped through a hole created by staff in that second enclosure 
in order to evaluate the dig barrier there. Three of the foxes were found unarmed on the same day; two were herded back 
while the third was captured with a net and placed back into the enclosure. The fourth fox was found unharmed near the 
commissary 8 days later and captured with a net to be placed back into the enclosure. The enclosure did not adequately 
contain the animals. Primary enclosures must be constructed of such material and of such strength to safely contain the 
animals. Corrective actions were implemented at the time of inspection. 
3.127(d) 
   
Facilities, outdoor. 
Most of the animals within the facility have outdoor or sheltered housing. The chain link perimeter fence located behind 
the maintenance area and the parrot enclosures had the following deficiencies: 
- Large gaps, some reaching up to about 1.5 feet in height and others spanning long distances, were seen at the bottom 
of the fence in many different areas. 
- Thick vegetation overgrowth climbing and leaning over large sections of the fence created a ladder that may allow

unwanted animals to easily enter the facility.  
The lack of an adequate perimeter fence presents a safety risk to the animals within the facility in that there isn’t a 
sufficient barrier to keep animals and unauthorized persons out, or an adequate secondary containment system to hold 
animals that may escape their primary enclosures. The facility must ensure the perimeter fence is kept in good repair and 
at the proper height in order to stand as an adequate barrier to protect the animals within the facility. Correct by 
09/19/2024. 
 
This inspection and exit interview were conducted with facility representatives. 
 
 n
